de.esoco.lib.collection

Class CollectionUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.collection.CollectionUtil

  • public class CollectionUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility functions for the handling of collections.

      A comparator constant that compares enum by their names.

      • addMapEntry

        public static <K,V> void addMapEntry(java.util.Map<K,V> rTargetMap,
                                     java.lang.String sEntry,
                                     java.lang.Class<K> rKeyType,
                                     java.lang.Class<V> rValueType)
        Parses a single map entry and adds it to a map. An existing entry with the same key will be replaced. The string to be parsed must either have the format <key>=<value> or <key>:<value>.

        The key and value elements will be parsed by means of the method TextUtil.parseObject(String), which will throw an IllegalArgumentException on invalid elements. The key must have a length of at least one character, the value may be empty. See the documentation of TextUtil.parseObject(String)for allowed key and value formats and the corresponding datatypes. Any whitespace characters surrounding either the key or the value will be removed.

        The last arguments define the datatype classes of the key and value, respectively. The parsed key and value objects will be cast to this types before being inserted into the map. Therefore any type mismatch will cause a ClassCastException to be thrown.

        Parameters:
        rTargetMap - The map to insert the parsed key/value pair into
        sEntry - The entry string to be parsed
        rKeyType - The datatype of the key
        rValueType - The datatype of the value
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parsing of the map entry fails

      • apply

        public static <T> void apply(java.util.Collection<T> rValues,
                             Function<? super T,?> fFunction)
        Applies a certain function to all elements of a collection.
        Parameters:

      • collect

        public static <T,C extends java.util.Collection<T>> C collect(C rCollection,
                                                              Predicate<? super T> pCollect)
        Collects each element from a collection for which the given predicate evaluates to TRUE into a new collection of the same type as the input collection. Uses a static instance of a function returned by the method CollectionFunctions.collect(Predicate).
        Parameters:
        rCollection - The collection to collect elements from
        pCollect - The predicate to test the collection elements with
        Returns:
        A new collection containing the result

      • collect

        public static <K,V,C extends java.util.Collection<? extends K>> java.util.List<V> collect(java.util.Map<K,V> rFromMap,
                                                                                          C rKeys)
        Collects all values from a map with certain keys into a new list.
        Parameters:
        rFromMap - The map to collect the values from
        rKeys - A collection of map keys
        Returns:
        A new list containing the map values that match the given keys

      • collect

        public static <K,V> java.util.Map<K,java.util.List<V>> collect(java.util.List<V> rInput,
                                                               Function<? super V,K> fKey,
                                                               java.util.Comparator<? super V> rComparator)
        Collects a list of objects into a map of sub-lists stored under a certain key. The key is determined by applying a function to each object. If an ordering criterion is given the keys of the map will also be ordered by the same criterion.
        Parameters:
        rInput - The list of objects to collect
        fKey - The function that generates the key of an object
        rComparator - A comparator that defines the ordering of the map or NULL for none
        Returns:
        A map containing the lists of collected objects, ordered by keys

      • collectInto

        public static <K,V> void collectInto(java.util.Map<K,java.util.List<V>> rMap,
                                     K rKey,
                                     V rValue)
        Collects values into lists which in turn are stored in a mapping from keys to value lists. If no list exists for a certain key it will be created (as an ArrayList and put into the map.
        Parameters:
        rMap - The map to collect the value lists into
        rKey - The key to collect the value under
        rValue - the value to collect

      • combine

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T,C extends java.util.Collection<T>> C combine(C rFirst,
                                                                            java.util.Collection<? extends T> rSecond,
                                                                            java.util.Collection<? extends T>... rAdditional)
        Combines two or more collections into a new one. The new collection will be created by invoking newCollectionLike(Collection) with the first input collection. The iteration order of the result depends on the types of the input collections.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The first collection to combine
        rSecond - The second collection to combine
        rAdditional - Additional collections to combine
        Returns:
        A new collection instance

      • combine

        @SafeVarargs
public static <K,V> java.util.Map<K,V> combine(java.util.Map<K,V> rFirst,
                                                             java.util.Map<? extends K,? extends V> rSecond,
                                                             java.util.Map<? extends K,? extends V>... rAdditional)
        Combines two or more maps into a new one. If the first input map is an instance of LinkedHashMap the resulting map will be of the same type, otherwise it will be a regular map.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The first map to combine
        rSecond - The second map to combine
        rAdditional - Additional maps to combine
        Returns:
        A new collection instance

        public static <T> boolean contains(T[] rArray,

        rSearch - The element to search for
        Returns:

        Parameters:

        fKey - The function that generates the key of an element

      • find

        public static <T> T find(java.util.Collection<T> rCollection,
                         Predicate<? super T> pCriteria)
        Searches for a certain element in a collection. The returned element will be the first in the collection's iteration order for which the given predicate evaluates to TRUE or NULL if none could be found. Based on a static function returned by CollectionFunctions.find(Predicate).
        Parameters:
        rCollection - The collection to search in
        pCriteria - The predicate to test the collection elements with
        Returns:
        The resulting object or NULL if none could be found

        public static <T,L extends java.util.List<? super T>> void insert(L rList,
                                                                  T rBeforeValue,

        Inserts a collection of values before another value in a list. If the value to insert before doesn't exist the new values will be added to the end of the list.

        rList - The list to add the value to
        rBeforeValue - The value to insert the new value before
        rNewValues - The value to insert

      • intersect

        public static <T,C extends java.util.Collection<T>> C intersect(C rFirst,
                                                                C rSecond)
        Returns a new collection that contains the intersection of two collections, i.e. only the elements that are contained in both collections. The returned collection will be of the same type as the first input collection.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The first collection to intersect
        rSecond - The second collection to intersect
        Returns:
        A new collection containing the intersection of the arguments (may be empty but will never be NULL)

      • intersects

        public static boolean intersects(java.util.Collection<?> rFirst,
                                 java.util.Collection<?> rSecond)
        Checks if two Collections intersect. Returns true if at least one element is contained in both collections.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The first collection
        rSecond - The second collection
        Returns:
        TRUE if the collections intersect

      • join

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T> T[] join(T[] rArray,
                                         T... rAdd)
        Copies an array and additional elements of the same type into a new array of that type and returns it.
        Parameters:
        rArray - The original array; it's elements will be copied to the start of the new array
        rAdd - The elements to add; these will be copied to the end of the new array
        Returns:
        A new array, containing both the original array and the additional elements

      • join

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T> T[] join(T[] rFirst,
                                         T[] rSecond,
                                         T[]... rArrays)
        Copies multiple arrays into a new array of the same type and returns it. Invokes the method join(Object[], Object...) for each array.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The first array
        rSecond - The second array
        rArrays - Optionally additional arrays
        Returns:
        A new array, containing all elements of the original arrays in the order of the arguments

      • map

        public static <I,O,L extends java.util.List<I>> java.util.List<O> map(L rList,
                                                                      Function<? super I,O> fMapping)
        A convenience variant of map(Collection, Function) for lists. this is necessary because it is not possible to couple the type of the input collection with that of the output collection because collections are generic types.
        See Also:
        map(Collection, Function)

      • newCollectionLike

        public static <T,C extends java.util.Collection<T>> C newCollectionLike(C rCollection)
        Returns a new collection with the same logical type (i.e. collection interface) as another collection if it can be determined. Otherwise a new LinkedHashSet will be returned as an order-preserving collection.
        Parameters:
        rCollection - The other collection
        Returns:
        The new collection

      • next

        public static <E> E next(java.util.Collection<E> rCollection,
                         E rElement,
                         boolean bWrap)
        Returns the next element in a collection. The collection will be searched for the given element and if it is found, the element immediately after it (in the collection's iteration order) will be returned. If the bWrap parameter is TRUE and the searched element is the last one in the collection the first element will be returned, even if it is the same as the searched element. The result will be NULL if the collection is empty, if the searched element is not found, or if it is the last element and bWrap is FALSE.
        Parameters:
        rCollection - The collection to search
        rElement - The element to search for
        bWrap - If FALSE NULL will be returned as the next element of the last one, else the first element will be returned
        Returns:
        The next element or NULL for none

        Returns:
        A new ordered map instance

      • parseMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object> parseMap(java.lang.String... rEntries)
        Parses a list of map entries and returns a new object map containing them.
        See Also:
        parseMap(Class, Class, String...)

      • parseMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object> parseMap(java.lang.String sEntries,
                                                                        char cSeparator)
        Convenience method that parses a string containing a list of map entries in the format "map entry 1<separator>map entry 2< separator>..." and returns a new map containing the parsed entries. Neither keys nor values can contain the separator character. Any whitespace characters surrounding the map entries will be removed.
        Parameters:
        sEntries - The entry string to be parsed
        cSeparator - The separator character between key value pairs (will be used in a call to Pattern.split()).
        Returns:
        A new map containing the parsed entries
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parsing of a map entry fails
        See Also:
        parseMap(String...), Pattern.split(java.lang.CharSequence)

      • parseMap

        public static <K,V> java.util.Map<K,V> parseMap(java.lang.Class<K> rKeyType,
                                                java.lang.Class<V> rValueType,
                                                java.lang.String... rEntries)
        Parses a list of map entries and returns a new map containing the parsed entries. The resulting map will return it's entries in the same order in which they are defined in the variable argument list.

        The first two parameters define the datatypes of the key and value elements, respectively. Each parsed key and value will be cast to this types. Therefore any type mismatch will cause a ClassCastException to be thrown.

        Parameters:
        rKeyType - The datatype of the key
        rValueType - The datatype of the value
        rEntries - The list of entry strings to be parsed
        Returns:
        A new map containing the parsed entries
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parsing of a map entry fails
        See Also:
        parseMapEntries(Map, Class, Class, String...)

      • parseMapEntries

        public static <K,V> void parseMapEntries(java.util.Map<K,V> rTargetMap,
                                         java.lang.Class<K> rKeyType,
                                         java.lang.Class<V> rValueType,
                                         java.lang.String... rEntries)
        Parses an array of map entries and inserts them into a map. Existing entries with equal keys will be replaced. The strings to be parsed must be of the format <key>=<value> or<key>:<value>. Both the key and the value elements must be parseable by the method TextUtil.parseObject(String), else an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        rEntries - The entry strings to be parsed
        rTargetMap - The map to insert the parsed key/value pairs into
        rKeyType - The datatype of the key
        rValueType - The datatype of the value
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parsing of a map entry fails
        See Also:
        addMapEntry(Map, String, Class, Class)

      • parseStringMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> parseStringMap(java.lang.String... rEntries)
        Parses a list of map entries and returns a new string map containing them. Each entry will be split into key and value strings by means of the method splitMapEntry(String) which will then be added to the map without further conversion.
        Parameters:
        rEntries - The map entries to parse
        Returns:
        A new string map containing the key-value pairs from the entries

      • previous

        public static <E> E previous(java.util.Collection<E> rCollection,
                             E rElement,
                             boolean bWrap)
        Returns the previous element in a collection. The collection will be searched for the given element and if it is found, the element immediately before it (in the collection's iteration order) will be returned. If the bWrap parameter is TRUE and the searched element is the first one in the collection the last element will be returned, even if it is the same as the searched element. The result will be NULL if the collection is empty, if the searched element is not found, or if it is the first element and bWrap is FALSE.
        Parameters:
        rCollection - The collection to search
        rElement - The element to search for
        bWrap - If FALSE NULL will be returned as the previous element of the first one, else the last element will be returned
        Returns:
        The previous element or NULL for none

      • sort

        public static <K extends java.lang.Comparable<? super K>,V> java.util.Map<K,V> sort(java.util.Map<K,V> rInputMap)
        Sorts the elements of a map by the map key and returns an new ordered map instance (currently LinkedHashMap) that contains the ordered entries. The input map will not be modified by this call.
        Parameters:

        A new ordered map instance

      • sort

        public static <K extends java.lang.Comparable<? super K>,V> java.util.Map<K,V> sort(java.util.Map<K,V> rInputMap,
                                                                                    java.util.Comparator<K> rComparator)
        Sorts the elements of a map by the map key and returns an new ordered map instance (currently LinkedHashMap) that contains the ordered entries. The input map will not be modified by this call.
        Parameters:
        rInputMap - The input map to sort
        rComparator - The comparator to sort by or NULL for the default (natural) order
        Returns:
        A new ordered map instance

public static <T extends Relatable> void sortBy(java.util.List<T> rList,
                                                              RelationType<? extends java.lang.Comparable<?>>... rTypes)

      • splitMapEntry

        public static java.util.regex.Matcher splitMapEntry(java.lang.String sEntry)
        Splits a single map entry into key and value strings. Returns a regular expression Matcher that contains the resulting key and value strings in the first and second group, respectively. Key and value must be separated by either a equal sign '=' or by a colon ':'. The first occurrence of one of these characters delimits the key value. Any further of these characters will be returned as part of the value group.
        Parameters:
        sEntry - The map entry string to be parsed
        Returns:
        A regular expression matcher initialized to return key and value in groups 1 and 2
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parsing of the map entry fails

      • subtract

        public static <T,C extends java.util.Collection<T>> C subtract(C rFirst,
                                                               C rSecond)
        Returns a new collection that contains the subtraction of two collections, i.e. the elements that are only contained in the first argument collection. The returned collection will be of the same type as the first input collection.
        Parameters:
        rFirst - The collection to subtract the second from
        rSecond - The collection to subtract from the first
        Returns:
        A new collection containing the intersection of the arguments (may be empty but will never be NULL)

      • toString

        public static java.lang.String toString(java.lang.Object[] rInput,
                                        java.lang.String sSeparator)
        Convenience method to return a string representation of an object array. Invokes Arrays.asList(Object...) to convert the input argument into an iterable object.
        See Also:
        toString(Iterable, String)

      • toString

        public static java.lang.String toString(java.lang.Iterable<?> rInput,
                                        java.lang.String sSeparator)
        Returns a string representation of the elements in an Iterable instance. The additional parameter defines the string that will be inserted between the elements. The separator will only be added between elements, not after the last element.
        Parameters:
        rInput - An Iterable instance containing the input objects
        sSeparator - The string to be inserted between elements
        Returns:
        A string representing the iterated elements

      • toString

        public static <T> java.lang.String toString(java.lang.Iterable<T> rInput,
                                            Function<? super T,?> rElementConversion,
                                            java.lang.String sSeparator)
        Returns a string representation of the elements in an Iterable object. Each element will be converted to a string with the given function. The string parameter defines the separator string that will be inserted between the elements. It will only be added between elements, not after the last element.
        Parameters:
        rInput - The Iterable instance
        rElementConversion - A function to convert the iterated elements
        sSeparator - The string to be inserted between elements
        Returns:
        A string representing the iterated elements

      • toString

        public static java.lang.String toString(java.util.Map<?,?> rMap,
                                        java.lang.String sJunction,
                                        java.lang.String sSeparator)
        Returns a string representation of the contents of a map. The two additional parameters define the strings that will be inserted between keys as well as values and map entries, respectively. The map entry separator will only be added between entries, not after the last entry.
        Parameters:
        rMap - The map containing the source keys and values
        sJunction - The string to be inserted between keys and values
        sSeparator - The string to be inserted between map entries
        Returns:
        A string representing the map contents

      • transform

        public static <I,O> java.util.Collection<O> transform(java.util.Collection<I> rInput,
                                                      Function<? super I,O> rFunction)
        Transforms a collection by returning a new collection that contains the results of applying a certain function to all elements of the input collection. The class of the returned collection will be the same as that of the input collection, with element types defined by the output of the transformation function. The new collection instance will be created by invoking the method Class.newInstance() on the input collection's class. Therefore the class must provide a no-argument constructor (which is the case for all standard collection classes in the java packages).
        Parameters:
        rInput - The collection containing the input values
        rFunction - The function to apply to the collection elements
        Returns:
        The resulting collection (may be empty but will never be NULL)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If creating the result collection failed
